entry.et: Middle English narowe, from Old English nearu; akin to Old High German narwa scar

def.dt: :of slender width a long and narrow room
:of less than standard or usual width a narrow sidewalk
:woven in widths usually less than 18 inches (46 centimeters)
:limited in size or scope a narrow interpretation
:barely sufficient :close won by a narrow margin
:relatively rich in protein as compared with carbohydrate and fat
:to decrease the breadth or extent of :contract often used with down
:to decrease the scope or sphere of :limit often used with down narrow down the choices
:to lessen in width or extent :contract often used with down
:a strait connecting two bodies of water usually used in plural but singular or plural in construction
:a barge with a beam of less than seven feet (2.1 meters)
:lacking in tolerance or breadth of vision :petty

entry.et: probably alteration of strait and narrow; from the admonition of Matthew 7:14(Authorized Version), “strait is the gate and narrow is the way which leadeth unto life”

def.dt: :the way of propriety and rectitude used with the
